1yESktMYSzOOcoyfx-9JZw.text: Woodlands! Curious name for a vegetarian restaurant. More like deforestation. And I would recommend immediate defenestration for the chef. Let me explain As curry afficionados and backed up with Vince Cable's enthusiastic recommendation, this place seemed ideal for a tasty and reasonably priced meal. The food was ok but nothing special, though the bill was pretty hefty at £69 for 2. In fact ridiculously hefty for a very average vegetarian meal. Food + wine came to £52.50 equating to a service charge of around 33%. Ok, maybe it serves us right for not thoroughly checking the bill and maybe they made a genuine mistake. BUT that was only the beginning of our walk in the woods as both my friend and I suffered major, and there's no way of putting this politely, toilet malfunction, on a scale I haven't experienced since backpacking around the subcontinent over 20 years ago. His started about 30 minutes after saying goodbye, mine the next morning. No matter, I'm still suffering the effects 36 hours later as I type these words after most of my flora and fauna have been thoroughly ravaged As Oscar Wilde might have said, to suffer one indignity is bad enough but to suffer two on the trots is bad form. I suspect the runny spinach may have played a partI would have given 0 stars if I could. So avoid. Like the plague. Unless you are happy to pay for the privilege of being a human petri dish. If you want a true taste of southern India then go to Balham and Tooting High Rd where the food is half the price and twice as nice.

6PTUap6ob06Ky0GPqFTr4Q.text: I wandered in here after my first choice said there was no room, and my second had a queue, but I enjoyed my Thali (a tray of mixed curries, a rice pattie and a pancake stuffed with potato and peas plus a dessert in this case) and managed to almost finish the lot! The service was excellent. The waiters were thoughtful, considerate and interested in my opinion of the food. They helped me with the choice of Thali, as there were 4 to choose from. Not an outstanding meal, but I could taste all the ingredients.

Y4-GU3De6v1QU24wwEGE0w.text: This peculiar vegetarian restaurant is fine to visit if you're in the area, everywhere else is full and you really want to eat Indian food. The reason that it's not a great place to eat is mainly due to the sometimes unfriendly staff and the seating layout. Most of the seating is to be found hidden right at the back of the restaurant but there is some right in the window at the front which is where they place people first to make the restaurant look full. Prices are quite steep too, but if you're careful about what you order then it is possible to eat relatively cheaply. Don't be totally put off by the negative points though. the food is generally very good.

Vgn5gql9C8l5DK6Jf8jr1Q.text: This place rocks! In the words of my 10 year old daughter "the channa masala is to die for! " I agree, it was the best I have ever had and I consider myself quite an Indian connoisseur! The Dosa was light and yummy, the dal was delicious and the Merlot was smooth.  The lemon rice was a great acconpanyment and they had many many vegan choices!!!! The waitor was so nice, and we ended leaving all the choices to him, which was worth it. He was so helpful, friendly and knowledgeable. If you are in London I would make the effort to go here even if you are not vegetarian or vegan! Yummy!

fsaDxy8qOXnoE9Uio39JKg.text: Woodlands is the favoured restaurant in London for anyone who likes south Indian (Tamil Nadu) vegetarian cuisine (99% of Indian restaurants in Europe specialise in north Indian cooking and although they have lots of vegetarian dishes on the menu, few have south Indian specialities). Woodlands was opened about 20 years ago and is plain and unadorned, but the cooking and service are good, and and the food extremely tasty. South Indians like their food hotter than in the north, but not extremely so. However, everything is well spiced. Idosas, idlis, vadas and uttapams are the main dishes and are combined with sambhar (a type of dal), rasam (tamarind dal), dry and curried vegetables and pachadi (yogurt). Seasonings and herbs include coconut, peanuts, tamarind, chilies, cilantro (coriander) and fenugreek seeds. It's very usual to order a thali (see photo) which holds an assortment of small dishes including the sweets. But ordering a thali denies one the chance of having the amazing paper dosas, which are huge crispy pancakes (see photo), broken with the fingers and dipped into a spicy sauce (sambar). Mango lassi (yoghurt drink) is the best thing to drink with the meal and Indians like coffee after it. Woodlands has a small but decent wine list, but wine doesn't really go with Indian food and even less with south Indian cooking. If you really want to drink, a Kingfisher beer is best. Seating is in two areas - one as one enters and a long rather narrow room at the back. Sit in the front room for better atmosphere, but be aware of the cold wind from the door!

photos.caption: Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. A vegetarian thali
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. A masala dosa

F29hv1LTuZ43VGYAsNYHMQ.text: Amazing place. As you can see from the photo above, the meals are huge, look great and taste even better. The service is fast, with polite and helpful staff and swift turnaround of the orders. I can honestly recommend it to anyone, especially if you're just visiting London.

rEyEGI-1gxHwZ4MkdPqYhA.text: I have now been to Woodlands on two different occasions, and both times the experience has been divine. The staff is super friendly and the space is quiet, with very simple decor and no music--so different from many Indian restaurants! The thalis are especially good, but it's quite a lot of food for one person. On my most recent visit we opted to share several dishes: paneer tikka masala, vegetables jalfrezi, tarka daal, a lemon rice and a plain rice, and a potato-spinach dish whose name I've forgotten. All were great, but the paneer dish suffered from an overabundance of sauce and a dearth of paneer. Next time I might substitute a dosa, as it's a south Indian specialty. I'd also recommend starting with a sweet (or mango) lassi, which is refreshing and delicious.Overall, I think that the Indian food at Woodlands is the finest I've had so far in London.

9rFTNnxltDnytpBYPHlcgw.text: This was our first meal arriving in London and it was an incredible way to start our trip. The staff was incredibly friendly and the food was the best Indian my husband and I have ever had. We're vegan so I love that South Indian is already vegetarian and simplifies things for us. The vegan options are not necessarily labeled but the ingredients are listed and like I said, the staff is excellent. Amazing everything!

dl43HhM1tcWrPkhsQ6bmcQ.text: It was good food. However, I wasnt that familiar with Indian food and the waiter talked down to me instead of helping. I dont know i I would go again. Great food though!

MoEJLVPAokfqVAg5Ov9f1A.text: It was an interesting tasting menu but not the most amazing food.  On the fried side for many courses and parts so harder to be healthy at all

RN8T1d4BPvURs98oZ7dSoQ.text: Very solid meal  at a good price. I enjoyed the "New Delhi," and I am looking forward to going back and trying some of the many other great options they have.

LxDpwm3y4nVCcVeBQfVdYQ.text: Im not vegetarian.I was there for my vegetarian friends birthday dinner.The food was ok and it was pricy. But I am not sure about vegetarian indian place anyway...

o76CPRrxY061XRk6MksmDg.text: Wow! Best Indian food I've ever had, based on our experience you can't go wrong here. Small but charming restaurant, friendly staff. As the other reviews tell, you won't recognize all of the dishes on the menu - but everything we tried was delicious. Nice organic wine list too. I'm a vegetarian, hubbie is not - we both enjoyed Woodland immensely, this place is heaven for non-meat eaters...so many things to choose from. Enjoy!

VFSz3gjUWTN-4GYU4iHqLA.text: Great food and good service, the staff are quiet but attentive. Service was not rushed despite the place being packed out and the waiter was very helpful with recommendations. As a meat eater I found this vegetarian place great and would definitley recommend it to friends who are vegetarian. The place is relatively small and not much to look at, every bit of space is put to good use. If you are looking for a relaxed meal, this is somewhere nice to go.

5LQoxP9WxdEt6Je7pMHSCA.text: The food is good overall but of great variety, some dishes are excellent, others so-so. What is really annoying id the combination of starchy atmosphere with aloof service. The maitre and staff think they are at Claridges rather than an Indian vegetarian, you get my drift. Stay clear of the Thali too. It,was my second visit and I thought I'd give it a try. Poor value for money really, more steamed rice than variety and I have never had a Thali before that included your dessert in the same dish. All in all us goodbye from me as with the huge variety of good restaurants they need to try much much harder.

7uLDWDJj1ydd1osyclBIEQ.text: Seems like most people visit this restaurant after failing to get a table at the steak house opposite, but I ended up here through a recommendation. Given the choice between waiting in the cold for a steak or Woodlands I'd go with the latter.They've got an interesting menu which goes we'll beyond the usual masala/ korma/ vindaloo I've grown to expect at Indian restaurants. They've got a great range of appetizers and even go as far as offering pre-appetizer snacks (you've go to admire their courage at trying to squeeze that extra course in!).The main courses consist of dosa (savoury filled Indian pancakes- delicious), thali platters, South Indian lentil pizzas and vegetarian mains, which are really nice and more like your usual curry recipe. If you're keen to try something new, make the most of the starters and dosa.Deserts looked great but in the end we just had coffee, which was spot on (strong and not too bitter). Overall I was really pleased with the food, the service and, considering this is Marylebone, the price.

8XqJ5h-ILUEITKwykEqmyw.text: I went to this place only a couple of times only coz my colleagues insisted on it .  But frankly, I personally didn't like this place.. Food is okay nothing too great but the service is pathetic. 4 of us had gone for lunch, we waited for the waiter to get some water to the table. After 5 mins of a fruitless wait, I asked for water. oppps only I asked for water so the waiter just gets one glass of water. Then I had to ask for water for everyone else. This happened on all occasions. They have a buffet for lunch. One of my colleagues decided to order an entree instead of having the buffet.. BIG mistake. The rest of us finished having our lunch and dessert and this poor fella was still waiting for his lunch to arrive. The Manager gives an excuse that the buffet food was getting over so the cooks were busy trying to refill that.. Seriously................ not again...

sRxte6DBL-I8qVC-1hp4FQ.text: Wholesome South Indian food Everyone should try this food. Woodlands is a chain in India and I personally would welcome the chain starting up in the UK. The food is amazing! Flavours that put your mind in a spin! Wake up Britain food that's what I would call it. These ancient techniques are properly interpretted and the flavours haunt anyone with a good palate. Staff = friendlyPrice = average Atmosphere = not remarkableFood = A must have for the 'Palate Memory' an introduction to a host of culinary boundaries.

OW37UAcmTDQJBW2vnImnGQ.text: Best Indian food in Marylebone. You hardly notice a lack of meat in all the dishes. The servers are very allergy conscious as well and know the menu backwards and forwards. Four stars only because like most London restaurants there is sometimes a long wait to be served.

Ly2-vKvKMTU32oyYwFAaUQ.text: We showed up at the vegetarian only Woodlands late on a Friday after work and a few pints. Unfamiliar with much of the menu, we trusted the waitstaff to recommend the orders for our group of four. The Tandoori starter was phenomenal and had something for everyone's tastes. The potato pancake wraps that came next were also stellar and are the house specialty. Highly recommended. Finally the three shared curries were also a hit.I'm going to go out on a limb and say it is one of the most filling vegetarian meals around and is a great value to boot.

efi30MjAW1zLHtermdNazA.text: the carrot-ginger-apple fresh squeezed juice, as your aperitif before even smelling your papadum is a MUST : )) LOVE it!didn't seem to get as much business as the restaurant accross from it, but def heard and would write better reviews for this one!!!we got the sampler appetizer platter, which next time, i will skip (soooorrryyy)... but just not a fan of fried stuff :-/the dosas are yummy, so is the lemmon rice, the tikkas and the big platters. I can't say that it's HIGH value, but can understand that 50% or more of the price probably goes to rent and utilities alone... so i guess that is acceptable.Service - very attentivedecor and ambiance - it felt dark in there, but not romantic dark, more like 5 out of 8 of bulbs just went out, but it's clean, and there is authentic indian music in the background, at really low volume... which I could use a little higher of, as it would make a nice background once one starts talking (but maybe that's just me).still - recommend the ginger-apple-carrot juice (ask for no ice -this way you get 13 ml more : )))tasty, will def go back if i have the chance!

EYar28nE_DiDljBicxqspw.text: Both this location in Marylebone and the one at Piccadilly offer great food at a good price.  I'll be back soon!

IF1wJIex2a2ATOvKNeCFhQ.text: slightly upscale delicious vegetarian southern indian food in the lovely area of marylebone. the service was extremely friendly and absolutely top notch.the food was fresh, plentiful, very light tasting. the chutneys were absolutely delicious, i couldn't get enough of the mint chutney. the papadums were among the lightest and tastiest i've ever had.prices are moderate, but well worth it for a lovely dinner. a great place to take a date.

l9vXQV2bmXGbcA3xiJB5oA.text: Awful. Over fried poriyal.  Highly oily ragi dosa and vadai. We were excited to see quinoa upama on  the menu only to be disappointed by the portion size (barely half a cup). Overpriced and poor value. Is the brown rice really brown? I am not sure. There are far better South Indian vegetarian places in West London. You'd be wasting your appetite, time and money here.

ZIuzLD0kc8yAaNNhLeMt7w.text: I went with my sister, brother-in-law, and my 4 month old niece for lunch. My family had been there before and asked the proprietor to just bring a selection of dishes. We received some standard fare, like dosas, but also some unique items I'd never seen previously. Everything was great!The staff were very accommodating.

photos.caption: Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom

C7urDgnMwzF6Owez7kxcjQ.text: We really didn't do much research before going here, but I'm glad we took the risk. Really delicious and clean tasting vegetarian Indian cuisine located on a quiet street in posh Marylebone.  Ordering 3 mains plus a carb (rice and/or naan) is enough for 2 people if sharing.  I really enjoyed the okra entree - there are two okra entrees on the menu and it is the second one (sorry can't remember what it is called!). The restaurant looks small from the outside, but once you step inside you'll notice that there is a dining room in the rear in addition to the front.  I'd request to sit in the front simply because it is brighter, there are windows and it is furthest away from the wonky shaped restroom. The waiter was really helpful and advised us on what to order. I will definitely return.

55hMbrVBWhkEchtiJZbonA.text: On my second visit the waiter remembered me and offered to seat us in my 'usual spot' which was pretty neat.The food here is good. For lunch, the vegetable jazeera, one of the dosas (basically an Indian crepe), raita and rice make a good, insanely filling meal to split between two people. It's not too pricey, weekday afternoons are calm, and there's a nice atmosphere to while away time in. And apparently the dosas ARE gluten-free, which makes me happy!

hixQ5GnwlIPOvctchAWlBQ.text: Really pleased to come across the rare gem. As a Vegan, I really struggle to find a decent restaurant to eat a hearty meal that thinks Vegan equals lentil and raw food!  The staff are really friendly and welcoming and the food tastes really good. Recommend their coconut Naan bread and a curry sauce that sadly, the name eludes me. Highly recommended.

pVnb3OWgUEuQQgCbPKuMGQ.text: Thank you Yelp. This was a great choice as the food was good, the service was quick, and the dinner was not too expensive. We ordered a lot of food and I don't think you can go wrong, especially when you ask for the waiter's recommedation. A crowded restuarant usually means they are doing something right.

QW37tSqzY0HNWk---nihDQ.text: I like food. You like food. However, I am a fatty, and probably fatter than thou, therefore my opinion carries more weight.Twinkle-toed we ascended from the bowels of Bond street tube, our thoughts turning to Tarka Dall and chappattis. The crisp air sharpened our hunger and Christmas lights (in  November?) sparkled on the lovely Marylebone High street. Charming.On entering Woodlands we were kindly offered the worst table in the house, which we politely declined. We were led to a table surrounded by cackling diners, belllowing their approval of each other.What would you like my dear? I screamed over the noise. The woodlands mixed starter platter, Dall, rice and lentil pizza please! She shouted in my ear-trumpet. What? And.... Oh dear. The mixed starter had obviously been hanging around a fair while, and was pretty bloody awful. Lentil pizza? A soggy failure.The dall was dull, the rice gloopy and repellent, as if a pack of butter had been stirred in a the last minute.Anyone reading this would do well to head to Drummond street, enter the sacred halls of Diwana and eat wonderful food for less than half the price. The only saviour was the service, which was speedy and friendly. My partners only comment? disgusting. And she's the vegetarian.

a1rOdlGemp42DjA8eZ6f8w.text: Excellent place for south Indian food. Great taste and the staff are very friendly.

LHecr-ngxRPlUvlr3eU1bw.text: There are not quite enough of reasonably priced and well-located restaurants in London which serve up freshly made and tasty South Indian fare. Or maybe I'm just an ignoramus who needs to know more. Either way, here is an establishment I had heard of so many times through many of my Indian friends that I felt ashamed that I hadn't been there yet. On a random weeknight, the boyfriend and I felt a craving for South Indian cuisine but couldn't bear the thought of making a trek to East Ham to fulfill said craving when voila, we remembered about the much-heard-of Woodlands near Piccadilly Circus station. We made our way with no small degree of excitement and a mighty appetite - we were not planning on holding back that night.When one sets out to a South Indian establishment, one does not expect a decent offering in terms of chaat variety. Chaat, FYI, refers to snacks/appetisers best had in North India at street-side vendors; it is essentially Indian junk food that evokes memories of home for many Indians. It is not a South Indian phenomenon and imagine our delight when we discover the whole variety on offer in the menu. We shared an Aloo Papri Chaat (Crispy pastry rounds topped with potato, yoghurt and tamarind sauce) - perfectly made, full credit to the chef who can juggle Southern & Northern cuisines so well.I had the Onion Rava Masala Dosa (Cream of wheat pancake with sautéed onions and green chillies.Filled with the traditional potato, onions and peas mixture) and the boyfriend opted for the Mysore Masala Dosa (A delicious dosa cooked with butter, spicy 'red' chutneyand the traditional potato filling.) All Dosas are accompanied with Sambar (lentil dipping stew) and coconut chutney. Our long-suppressed cravings were much satiated and in our elation, we let ourselves go and even went ahead and ordered another Onion Rava Masala Dosa to split between the two of us - making it a greedy 1.5mains each between the two of us :P The dosas were crisp on the outside and soft on the inside - just the way they are meant to be and the sambar was redolent with spices and flavour, which is important...the best of dosas can be ruined by a bland serving of sambar.We were rather full by the end of that and had to ruefully skip dessert but we lingered on for the Masala Tea - thumbs up for this too.The prices are reasonable for the locality, best not to compare against the dirt-cheap establishments in East Ham. The service was great, we appreciated the thoughtfulness of the staff to split the dosa into halves, which we hadn't asked for and was really helpful.This restaurant is a vegetarian establishment but there is not a chance you will feel the absence of meat on your platter as you explore the offerings on the menu. I am a meat-lover to boot, but I highly recommend that you check this restaurant out.

DY7tBYIGkcpPym8-Xa_vXA.text: Very nice Indian cuisine.The music wasn't too loud, the staff was friendly and the mood just very relaxed.Would def. go here again and would also recommend it to anyone who's vegetarian.

6aBg0tvDyDUhOCUjbstIMQ.text: Very good Indian food. We like to go there although we are not even trying to find a vegetarian place. The seating in the front by the window is very pleasant, the back room is a little tight but still fine.The various breads are excellent, the food overall is very very good. Everything is very flavorful, yet not at all greasy or heavy. Best approach is to get a few dishes to share, and grab come rice and bread to go with it. The staff is very helpful. Ask the waiters for recommendations if you are not sure.

0atB6lw-A8qUhbkhHiRE-Q.text: The food was great, the atmosphere was relaxed and welcoming, but the real highlight of this place was the incredibly friendly and patient service. We can definitely recommend this great vegetarian restaurant.

reekl48tpozw31C_s1GIFw.text: Excellent Indian vegetarian food. Spices are perfectly used here and they cook the traditional way. They avoid most oils and butters that most Indian restaurant use to enhance flavors. Here you can have Indian vegetarian food at its best. Just go with some time to spare. They are usually full and some dishes require some extra time to be delivered to your table.

FK4p_j9d3rBHdiq9ewmePg.text: Fantastic from top to bottom.  The cheese tikka masala was a joy, and the dohi is beautiful.

6F56XnHd-GC8jq-6Advgwg.text: First some background. Indian food is very diverse. What you eat in most Indian restaurants covers about 0.001% of the  flavours, meats, spices & methods used in Indian cooking.South Indian cooking, for instance,uses very little garlic, creme, butter and is primarily vegetarian. Woodlands is a south Indian restaraunt and it specializes in dishes like vada, Dosa, uttapam, idli, avail. If you go to woodlands and ask for chicken tikka masala or tandoori whatever or Saag paneer, u are doing yourself a disservice.The rule at woodlands is "if you've heard of that dish before, don't order it" Happy exploring.

W8ZajibiUhcnwupWmYmJ4g.text: The food is very good and I have always liked coming here. Very disappointed with the service today though - have been waiting for more than 40 min and it's not even full house!

DL0XE-1pqO22JpPCOj2gTQ.text: I'm not a vegetarian but this place is great !! So much flavour ! I had the London Royal Thali set menu while my friend ordered the Mysore Royal Thali set menu and we shared both... We had to be rolled out of there ! The chutneys had an amazing flavour ... I never knew one place could offer such a large extensive vegetarian menu ... Great place !

Ieppin-lw0VOMPMqEapRMw.text: It's not the cheapest, but it's reasonable. I've eaten at all of the Woodlands restaurants a number of times. The Hampstead one is shocking, but the Marylebone and Leicester Square ones are fine. The paper masala dosa is very nice, and it's fun too. But if they serve it overcooked don't be afraid to send it back. The lunch boxes they do are very good value for the amount of food you get  I used to get them when I worked in a very posh office in Mayfair and enjoy the horror on the faces of my very snobby colleagues :-)

19iZI0xuVEfNlfAvfkOl2A.text: love indian food. turned vegetarian for health reasons. they have 3 locations, we went to marylebone lane. very good, unusual food. some dishes were sensational. the poori from the cold appetizers for example. dosas all looked good but didn't try. medu vada, fried lentil donuts, a bit boring. atmosphere/decor somewhat lacking, borderline depressing. front room seemed more cheerful. service very friendly. civil prices for London. i would go back and try more.

4r9YnsvDAqK735GJ_nCKcQ.text: Some of the best Indian food I have ever had! A must-try! We started with a selection of uttapams (small lentil "pizzas"), and a crêpe-like dosa filled with potatoes and other vegetables. Both were exquisite. For our main dishes, we had a vegetable sambar, which was deliciously spiced but did not have quite enough vegetables, baingan bharta, which was fabulously thick, and a delicious okra dish called bhindi kootu which was unlike anything I have ever had. The major flaw of this place is that rice is additionally priced; it does not automatically come with your food. Other than that, Woodlands is highly recommended.

wIuR0m906paPFHDcXA4lSA.text: Excellent food.  The waiter was not as friendly as she should be, but I guess that is London. They don't offer water as I am accustomed to in the good old USA. We kept asking for it. One thing is for sure the quality of food is much better than the Woodlands in Artesia, CA.  Just need more friendlier waiters.

DehGkzpf9W7wbjX3lvRCqg.text: I am really into indian food and i am a vegetarian, so i was really happy when my colleagues told me that we are going to have dinner at the Woodlands. We started with a mixed plattern of little bits and bites like Cashew Nut Pakora and Masala Poppadums ( Savoury crips garnished with chopped onion, tomato, cucumber and green chilli and coriander) All was really good. But my personal highlight of the night was the Masala Dosa! It was acutally the best Dosa i had, since i have left India three years ago. I would come back only for the Dosa!!! For the main course we had some different dishes coming up with riche or Butter Naan. All were very tasteful and the way they were served seemed really authentic to me. The service was good, always making sure that we had enough to drink and are enjoying our food. As deserts we had Gulab Jammum ( Golden condensed milk dumplings in a rose and saffran syrup) Amazing! You really gotta try this. If there would be one thing i would be picky about, it would be the interieur of the dining room in the back of the restaurant. It is not really the most relaxing place to sit in. At least the plastic flowers hanging down from the ceiling could be changed into real ones, but in a way this also fits to India.. ;-)

photos.caption: Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. Best Dosa since my last stay at India!!! Soooo tasty.
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. i couldn't figure out what it was, but it tasted awesome.
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. Yammyy mushuooms and broccoli

tCXlKNCMU7TpG7wK0XyCtg.text: Really nice find in marylebone. All our dishes were excellent. Particularly the poori appetizer. Veggie stew well spiced and interesting. Also wonderful dal and the paneer tikka masala was lovely.  Nice quiet atmosphere. Definitely will return to sample more of the interesting menu.

dgT0tQ9In5ELY96oJRTswQ.text: I came here with a bunch of my colleagues from work - in fact, there was eleven of us. Instead of going through the menu and painfully having to debate on what we should order, we simply left the decision with the kind waiter...and the only questions he had for us was: are you hungry or very hungry? do you like it spicy or very spicy?Soon the food was rolling in...and while I really can't remember the specific names of any of the dishes, I do remember that as a whole they tasted really nice. (The waiter actually explained each dish upon placing it on the table, but the Indian names are always giving me a hard time...) Needless to say, this being a vegetarian/vegan restaurant (Southern Indian cuisine), there were lots of dishes with lentils & peas, which might be an adventure for some stomachs - so make sure to eat some kulfi ice-cream at the end of the dinner to sooth your stomach!Overall, I really enjoyed my dinner here - I especially like the fact that this place is so not Marylebone!

E2cg_d8LmauHsOV6sj53Tw.text: One of the top 10 best meals I have ever had was at Woodlands. This is no slight compliment, as I've eaten at many of the top restaurants in the U.S. The food was so flavorful and delicious that I worried that I was disturbing the man reading his newspaper next to me because I couldn't control my exclamations of delight as I was eating. It's worth noting that I eat mostly vegetarian and that I am not an incredibly adventurous Indian food eater. So if you are a person that is constantly trying the most exotic, fiery hot things on the menu, we may have different palates. But no matter who you are, I doubt you'll feel misled if you take my advice and come here sometime - preferably while very hungry.The decor of the restaurant is pretty clean and attractive. Nothing that really stood out to me. And the service is good but not great. It is really the food - and the vegetarian emphasis - that brings people here.I personally loved the "set meals" which give you an appetizer, large main course consisting of 6-7 dishes of various foods, and dessert. My favorite one was the New Delhi, and I believe the one I liked second most, which my wife enjoyed, was called the London. They're the bottom two meals on that section of the menu. As far as bread, the dosa (crispy-yet-soft shell filled with potato-y goodness), latka-like potato pancake, and all forms of naan were delectable.I only regret that I live 9 hours from London, or else I'd come here once each month to treat myself.

U5wSmwqEP0a0oKKFBdRLSA.text: If you are in London and near the Marylebone area, this is a must stop for dinner! My husband and I are not vegetarian and this was one of the best Indian cuisines I have ever had.

HnBekHC5Cf8GdACEVeL97A.text: Woodlands serves great vegetarian Indian food. We started with an assemble of appetizers that was truly amazing. Everything was unique and delicious. I especially loved the yoghurt shots - you have to try those!I chose dosa for the main course and while it was rather nice, I have to admit that I liked the appetizers better, as they were much more interesting. The dosa had slightly spicy potato filling, but I personally think that it could use some more spices. Still, a very nice meal.The service was great: very helpful, always there, very attentive. The only thing that  didn't like was the interior: very simple and not really stylish. It doesn't matter though, because it's still worth to come for the food itself.

photos.caption: Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. Dosa

y6yZ4XfQ9bIWYSWWoWMYQA.text: This review is for a quick lunch we had after walking around Hyde Park and Marlybone area.  My husband is South Indian so a major food snob when it comes to restaurants that serve "his food".  Service was fine, as much as I could expect from a normal Indian restaurant.   I ordered the idli/sambar, which was light and fluffy, with the sambar lentil soup which was flavorful but not too spicy.  My husband had the rava onion dosa, which is made up of fermented lentils and rice and comes out in a pancake consistency.  My requirements for a dish like this is that it needs to be crispy but not oily, and this place absolutely brought that to the table.  Next time, I will try the uttapam, which is a thicker version of the dosa.

2uy9tvXa-Se-JkwVDO8GsQ.text: Really good vegetarian Indian restaurant. We ate:Vegetable Korma - Very nice and different from what I usually expect from a KormaVegetable Kofka - I really liked this spicy curry, but my wife was less keen.Cashew Pakora - like an Indian version of popcorn. I probably wouldn't order this again at a restaurant, but it would go well with a movie!Mini Lentil Pizzas - not what they were called I think, but that's what they were. Nice too, particularly with the accompanying sauces.Bread Basket - There was a naan, a very interesting green flecked one and then one that was kind of like a large dry biscuit (could probably have done without that one).The mains were served in these unusual bowls where the mouth was at an angle. I was regularly alarmed as I thought that they were about to fall over. Kinda funny.Would come here again, for sure!

qhnkZIK8EbuyayjyYy1dRA.text: Best Indian Veggie in London! High quality food from South India and the Malabar Coast.Yummy fresh veggies, coconut, lentils and curries, savory crepes and pancakes. Amazing and expansive spectrum of unique flavors that are miles away from the traditional Anglicized Balti and Tikka fare.Try the onion rava masala (crepe with potatoes), medu vada (fried lentil donuts), idlis (puffy rice pancakes), utthapam (Indian pizza) or the Thali for a tasting menu. Don't forget the sambar, chutney and rasam.If you like ethnic foods you will love this place. And for the less adventurous, you will be well within your comfort zone.Nice ambience and cozy location in the heart of Marylebone.

yqefNyw0EbewWikyspjENA.text: One advice: go eat here :-)I normally like a bit of meat in my food, but still we decided to go try this place which we often see while passing by.The place is quite simple, no thrills in the decoration, but is still comfortable and service is friendly.Now to go to the point: the food is simply excellent. I discovered a part of Indian food I had not clue about as I was more used to regular Indian food with meat.Here the tastes are even more elaborate, using delicious spices and showing much more refinement.Loved the starters, loved my kind of pancake with a mix of spinach and lentils, and after trying the chickpeas curry, we tried the recipe at home as it was delicious :-)

aGLx3ErfvxqZYUU8upUTGg.text: Date Night last week brought us to Woodlands. The restaurant is very nicely decorated with a kind of casual romantic feel. The ladies room is odd... Go through the door in the dining room, walk up some exquisitely steep stairs and into a tiny little closet of a restroom. We decided that the Cashew Nut Pakora sounded interesting as a starter... cashew nuts, quick fried in a crunchy batter. Our impression? Indian popcorn. It was definitely interesting, but I'm not sure that we'd go for the same again next time.The four mini South Indian Lentil pizzas came next. Each had it's own flavour, but tasted largely the same. Though they didn't taste very different, we really enjoyed them. The coconut chutney was refreshing and flavourful. The mysore chutney was a bit spicy for me, but my heat loving husband really enjoyed it.For our mains, we got the Woodlands Kofta and the Woodlands Korma. I'm a Korma fan. It's my go to meal, and though it wasn't the best I've ever had here at Woodlands, it was really nice. We decided on getting the Kofta because it was very unique and we hadn't heard of anything like it before. The creamy potato, spinach and pumpkin dumplings in a rich tomato gravy was every bit as interesting as it promised to be. This was not a dish I'd order again. Chris finished it off and seemed like he thought it was okay. All in all, we enjoyed our meal, but Woodlands is not quite up to the caliber of Diwana Bhel Poori House.

SHvoYTrxC3jVsvxQCgFIYQ.text: Ugh! How could anyone give this crappy, overpriced and pretentious place anything more than one star? Masala dosa was mushy and tasteless inside with a completely wrong outside. The various curries we got were made with frozen vegetables and cooked in some sort of cheap grease. Rice, which usually comes with entrees was £3.50 and was served hard and COLD.They even charged 12.5% for service where there was none to speak of.

8pocmYH8EGw-48uxwFojVA.text: This was a wonderful dining experience. The all vegetarian menu was incredible and the food was amazing. Since we weren't super familiar with the cuisine on the menu, we all feasted on "tasting" type options. For starters we had two variety platters: the Woodlands Variety Platter and the "Tandoori Platter." Both were excellent and provided us with tons of different items to try for the first time. We had a great time sharing and discussing our favorite items. For dinner we had Thalis (whole meals comprised of a balanced mix of items from the menu). This included the Woodlands Thali and the London Royal Thali. For drinks members of our party had cocktails from the bar and  Mango Lassis. The food was so good. The only two issues were probably just bad-timing and likely won't be an issue for other diners in the future: (1) There is a heat wave in London currently and the air conditioning really wasn't cutting it. As an American who is spoiled and accustomed to refrigerated buildings when it's hot outside, it was pretty uncomfortable, especially when you add hot curries to your system. and (2) we were seated next to a large group (8 to 10 people) and they were very loud for our whole meal. We had difficulty hearing each other over their din so our dinner conversation was a challenge. Again, this is an excellent restaurant and a great place for anyone to try a wide variety of Indian foods without having to make too many choices on the menu. It's even a great place for meat eaters who think they won't enjoy vegetarian--it was that good! The issues we experienced probably won't be issues for others. I highly recommend this restaurant.

kcPNWaohjZanRTXo8Dzolg.text: This was probably some of the best Indian food I have ever had, though not cheap.The restaurant itself is a bit small (although this appears to be usual in London) and so it can get very loud if there are a couple of mid to large sized groups there.

etSMnXRUn98w8EM9L7rGbA.text: After hearing recommendations for Woodlands for ages, I finally made a point to have dinner there and now I can only wonder why I waited so long. Though I was dining alone, I was given a lovely table near the window and served with attention and courtesy. The thali selection was lovely and I had the Keralan thali on recommendation of the server. The food was deliciously prepared with just the right amount of spice. The flavours were full and varied and I enjoyed spending my time savouring each. I highly recommend the salted lassi with or after the meal. It is a refreshing complement.

SfPtzXJwL2PklTHhAuik5g.text: I had been meaning to go to Woodlands for years, hearing it had some of the best South Indian food in London, and it did not disappoint! North Indian and Bangladeshi food are easy to come by in London, but South Indian food less so. If you live in London, or if you're visiting London, it's close enough to central London that it's easy to make the trip on the tube.We started with a plate of assorted starters: mostly grilled vegetables and cheese. If you have never had a piece of grilled paneer (cheese), your life is not yet complete, so make sure to address that.  We shared a plate of uttapams and a gigantic paper dosa. Both were delicious and deeply satisfying with rich flavours. The reasonably priced wine list completes the evening. The interior was slightly decorated for the holidays, cutely, and in a not-too-fussy way. The place is formal not sloppy, but not super fancy like some of the other Indian places in the city.Gluten free notes: Almost all South Indian food is naturally gluten-free. Do not order anything with "rava" in it -- that means wheat. The non-rava dosas and other dishes are made out of rice and lentil. Our server knew what gluten was, and was able to give advice. Enjoy!

Qb9KcGJW7V9c_uEowupbnQ.text: I loved this place!  Great food, one of the best Indian restaurants I have been to.  Everything tasted fresh, and presentation was perfect.  Service was good, although they do close a bit early for London.One tip, they have a variety plate, can't remember what it is called, but it was really great and gave a good selection of foods.

03fRUmoGJJIWSMSVV05Gkg.text: Excellent food. Great service. Right price. Thanks to the other Yelpers for the recommendation. Having just moved here from SF, I was delighted to find a vegan option for southern Indian food! My dosa and naan were excellent and the staff couldn't have been friendlier or more helpful. I highly recommend this location, specifically but know there are other Woodlands around as well -- probably worth trying out.

q5WfY2mLNv7pmzjJwkizWA.text: Whilst I love Indian food, I always approach Indian restaurants with caution as I never understand the menu. It usually bears no resemblance to the home cooking I grew up with, particularly with the number of meat dishes on the menu as so much of India is vegetarian. Thankfully these days 'vegetarian' dishes are not consigned to the sundries part of the menu at the back and in the Woodlands they take pride of place. We asked them to bring a mix of appetisers to start us all off and the delighted us with a lovely variety, including he delightfully named and tasting yoghurt shots!I chose Chana Masala and the recommended bread that came with it, looking like a football that I took great pleasure in 'deflating' before it could be broken and shared easily with friends. All the food was excellent, with my main dish being served in a teasingly lop-sided bowl.We were a large (international, multi language) group and yet still received excellent service. The staff clearly know how to accomodate large groups and looked after all of us very well. Good value, great location, fabulous service. Recommended!

JUGgdMLYm3JUwaQH90g9_Q.text: Woodlands has an amazing vegetarian and vegan menu! They have an especially large Dosa menu which is also top notch. If you're looking for some delicious comfort food, I highly recommend Woodlands! The Daal Tarka (I know, they spell it this war round), was amazing, as always!I would, however, like to see the Naan bread on the vegan menu! (It was crossed out both times I visited). My only complaint is that the staff could definitely serve their customers faster. The second time I visited, we were the one of two tables (it was pretty early) and it still took ~10mins to get menus and some extra time to give our orders. From what I've seen in other reviews, the service tends to be the limiting factor. If Woodlands stepped this up, they would definitely get be closer to 5 stars for me.

ME4pZjK5LdaYDmvauKMSBw.text: Visited Woodlands when I was craving a Dosa and didn't want to venture too far from central London.I wouldn't say that it hit the spot because the dosa and accompanying chutney and sambhar were below average (2 star rating)the 3 stars comes from the very nice interior and wonderful service - perhaps I would come by to try their north Indian food but wouldn't advise their south Indian dishes.

27Ke2l3t6f7dsWqiYpFO9Q.text: I'd like to update my review simply because I've come here two more times since the review and service has been quite poor both times. I don't really mind waiting because I enjoy talking with people and having a nice relaxing meal, but both times they had difficulty giving us water, let alone refilling it.  The food is still great though.

photos.caption: Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. Vegetable korma and malabar
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. Malabar Avial stew
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. A lil bit of everything

iJBFXHol6IsqWUyWSn6E9w.text: Very bad Indian restaurant we are from states and went with family the food is expensive with very little quantity not enough for a kid,the staff had a rude behavior, we see mosquito in the rice and complained , staff not bothered to apologize and don't care attitude,This is insane and not good for anyone to visit this placePlease DONOT goto to this place,horrible experience.

6R3XktyBw6c2P3lH38dplQ.text: I'm torn as to whether I really love Woodlands or not.Whilst the food was pretty darn good... I felt it was very expensive for what we got. It was around £18 a head, and that's not counting drinks and in principle I hate having to pay extra for good vegetarian food - it should be available as standard! The staff were also not attentive and didn't really seem to care that we were there or not. It took a long time to order and for a nearly empty restaurant we had to hound them for the bill.The decor is very classy, it's a lovely restaurant with some great features (I loved the lampshades in the back portion of the restaurant). I did like the elegant design of the menu and how neat and tidy the place is. If you're trying to impress a date, or on a business lunch, I could see that this would be the place to go.We ordered a selection of dishes and the bread basket, and I loved how fresh it tasted and the juxtaposition of ingredients and spices... However this is something I feel that you should expect from a vegetarian restaurant. It's great that there were some usual flavours going on, however I could understand that those that would like to know what they should expect might be a bit apprehensive ordering here.My favourite dish was the Pesarettu Dosa with spinach and the Bhindi Masala (okra), which I would recommend. The Okra however is quite spicy.So to sum up:Pro's - Great vegetarian food with a range of unusual flavours. Classy decor.Con's - Staff and price.

S75rA6reG47g6k5f5_5P2g.text: I would give 5 stars but it was very pricey and rude workers. The vegetarian food is so excellent. I had the Masala, Spinach, Paneer Chettinad, Spicy Vegetable Mince, Sada.  The staff certainly need to work on their manners. I didn't want to pay 130£ to be disrespected. Anyway, the food was excellent.

xianszCpFbIt3lzqlBhBUQ.text: Loved their spinach chaat but wasn't impressed with bomb chaat. Idly was nice with good chutney and sambhar. Mushroom curry disappointed. Probably great for south Indian dishes only

AnKyT6PE6gscKTuiR78mwg.text: Would have liked to have given a 3 1/3 but Yelp doesn't do half stars and service was poor. The bar tender (woman behind the desk who was the o to one near us the entire meal didn't speak enough English to understand us or help us). The person guy who took our order and I assume owns the restaurant very clearly noticed our drinks empty several times and so did the others but didn't do anything about it. He even noticed me eventually refilling my glass from my water bottle at my feet I was so desperate and still did nothing! Upon finally flagging someone down and requesting water from someone he said ok and and noticed another girl refilling another tables waters and assumed we would get our waters filled (which we didn't so we had to then hunt her down). The Tika masala is NOT amazing as it states on the menu. The other food was ok.

4ZgxBQ-c3s51bZmixYb_Jg.text: Excellent food and service.We shared a bottle of organic red wine that was delicious and well priced.To eat, we ordered one of the sharing entrees, which came with five or six different dishes, the samosa app, and curried vegetables. All of this was delicious and very fresh tasting. Nothing was too saucy - everything was spot on! Also, loved the individual roses on each table, cute touch. Will definitely be back, as Marylebone High St is one of my favorite areas in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. Samosas!
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. Beautiful right?!

b-cER_AyvjtkpPM0v8cwbg.text: This restaurant has an overwhelming menu for vegetarians who are used to only having to choose from a small number of options! There are some really unique options on the menu, and the spinach ragi dosa was amazing; hearty, flavourful and something a bit different. The waitress was helpful, steering us away from a thali that's targeted at Jain patrons (why avoid delicious garlic if avoiding it isn't part of your religious practice?).

t0drPVUqGxjV_ncbH7K1uQ.text: Extremely arrogant and rude staff. So disgusted with the service that food became insignificant. Never felt so bad at any restaurant. For 20 minutes nobody even came to our table. Restaurant was not even busy. Only 4 tables were full...,So Disappointed and angry.

Y2PN6fDSQz8aZJS4i8DTrA.text: The food was above average. It's a popular place. We came here around 8:30 pm and it was still crowded. I came here three months ago so my memory of the meal is hazy. What I do remember, is the great service I got here. At the end of our meal, I was so stuffed. But dessert is my most important meal of the day so I asked for a menu to look over dessert. I was on the fence about getting dessert, so I was taking my time. Since it was nearing closing time, the owner (I assume he's the owner) was sitting next to our table reading a newspaper. I made eye contact with him and he asked me how dinner was. I told him it was great. Then he asked me if I was going to have dessert. I told him I was so full that I wouldn't get dessert because I wouldn't be able to finish it and didn't want anything to go to waste. He called a waiter over and told him to get me a little dessert. I told him no, it was okay, he didn't have to. But he insisted. So they brought me out a small portion of a dessert. AND they didn't charge me for dessert. A small gesture like this goes a long way.  I felt well taken care of, like I was family. If I visit London again, I would definitely eat here again.

gT2S0KZu7MD-ukLHDTFXYQ.text: It's vegetarian, which for me is a downside. The upside though is that it's legit! Worth a visit.

dJhLQWNt9f_9sUBz-LwFYg.text: I come here often for lunch.The people that own/run it are really nice, and the food is delicious and a very good value.  I get a £10ish lunch special which really fills me up something fierce! The samosas are covered in this delicious tamarind sauce and chickpeas - very different and delicious.The breads are fantastic as well - the lack of meat has resulted in their expertise in parts of the menu normal curry houses ignore.My only qualm is that the place can be pretty dead.  Fine as I usually eat there alone at lunch, but wouldn't necessarily wanna go with a group of friends (though that would necessitate having more than 2 friends -is three people a group?).

o3CGfsOdagV3bkRB_trziA.text: We were a bit hesitant about the all vegetarian menu, but we went with my brother who doesn't eat meat. We were all blown away by how delicious and flavorful the food was. The chili cheese naan was a definite highlight. We left feeling full but not gross the way you sometimes do after Indian. I would definitely go back and recommend it!

qPDLP48cxzmFbKPKUREmWw.text: Our cravings for some South Indian food led us to woodlands. Easily walkable from the Baker Street station this is situated in maryleborne high street. The interiors are rather simple, nothing much to write about. The menu comprises of both north and South Indian cuisines with a larger variety in the South Indian category. They have appetizers with street food selectors to grills. Of what we ordered I would recommend the Mysore dosa, the woodland variety platter, medu Vada and if you're looking for a proper 3 course meal then opt for one of the Thalis. The price point is high and not the service is not the best. With an establishment that has been around for long one would expect a warmer treatment and friendlier service. I think I would search for a better place for my South Indian grub the next time. Keep gobbling xx

n-K9vSCrBMKef9KwLAmUOw.text: The third time's a charm...On my first two visits, I liked Woodlands. Enough to keep coming back. My veggie pals always delight in their all veggie menu (and hey, we can all use a night to put our carnivorous ways to rest, right?) and they have the ability to seat a large group pretty easily in their back room. I've been in twice with groups of 12-15, and both have been handled very gracefully. In fact, I think they almost handle the bigger groups better! When I came with a gal pal one cold and rainy night, we had to beg for service (and were seated in the front window)...and waited for what seemed like an eternity for any request. With a big group? They are on it! May have just been an off night. The food is wonderful. Made with love, very tasty (and plentiful) options! I had the Woodlands Korma on my last visit and found it to be very tasty. Well portioned, and we all shared about 12 bottles of white wine...so were feeling quite festive as we exited. All of the appetizers were filled with victory, and the dosas I spied around the table were devoured without complaint...in fact, rounds of "mmmms" surely were heard around the world. All rice and naan orders come separately, so make sure to order a few of the basics and some of the more adventurous and creative varieties. Reservations can be made online, but I suggest calling. It's just a bit easier for them, I think. A nice treat in this neighborhood. Friendly service, great food and extremely vegetarian-friendly...

WV8KdkHXhfrbWhoWbXfHtg.text: My internet didnt work last night, so here is my review for Woodlands (with a few hours delay, but still oh so true):Ok, let me write this down quickly, before my body collapses in a food coma. Right now I find myself in between heaven and hell, heaven, because of the fantastic Indian food I just ate and hell because of the amount of food that I just ate. Lets put it this way: the food was so good that I just couldnt stop eating although my body probaply reached its capacities at some point around the 4th or 5th appetizier already. Joghurt shots (actual food, not drinks), Paneer Lal Mirch (Cubes of Indian cottage cheese) or Medu Vada (fried lentil doughnuts) just to name a few. Of all the main dishes I tried (we were about 11 people so there was a huge variety of flavors on the table), I think I liked the Woodlands Kofta best. The tomato gravy was just perfectly creamy and delicious.And the service? The service was just amazing. Friendly, fast and attentive. One of the waiters even presented us a lady finger at the table, because we didnt know what it was when we read the menu. Great, great, great! The interior did not blow my mind, but whatever, the dishes were delish! So here come my 5 stars for food, service and value prices.

photos.caption: Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. MYSORE MASALA DOSA - Dosa cooked with butter, spicy 'red' chutney and potato filling
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. PANEER LAL MIRCH - Cubes of  Indian cottage cheese
Photo of Woodlands - London, United Kingdom. SPECIAL BHAJJIA - Crispy fried onion fritters

qOdCA3zcgcOeiBbRKu6IMQ.text: I picked this restaurant having to find somewhere close where I could dine with a Vegan friend (having found this place on Yelp of course!).  I was a little bit apprehensive and worried that I might struggle to find something I could eat.  Although not a particular big meat eater some vegetarian/vegan places can be full of lentils and pulses (which I am not a fan of).  I was pleasantly surprised with the menu and actually struggled to thin down my selection of foods I wanted to try.  In the end I went with the Paneer Masala and pilau rice.  This was fantastic.  The type of meal you feel sad to see finish.  With my sweet tooth I tried dessert also.  Much of it sounded really sweet (even for me) but feel incomplete if I don't get my pud when out for a meal!  I opted for the condense milk dumplings with syrup (see how sweet does that sound!!!).  Again nicely surprise by it.  Yes, a tad sweet, but not bad at all.  I left with a full belly and the promise to be back to try the other dishes on the menu.Yum Yum Yum!

LRsfUstx1716b8GMci_FNw.text: Mysore masala dosa. Remember it. That's what you need to order if you come visit. I also love the okra dish which I can't remember the name of. Also try the batura (fried bread that looks like the shape of an American football). It's a great vegetarian restaurant so definitely worth the visit if you're in the area.
